clinical_study.brief_title: Massive Transfusion Protocol With Coagulation Algorithm
clinical_study.official_title: Introduction of a Massive Transfusion Protocol - Evaluation Over Three Years

brief_summary.textblock:
In 2008 at the University Hospital Zurich (USZ) a massive transfusion protocol was introduced. Based on laboratory diagnostics and point of care (POC) devices including ROTEM.
Goal of this retrospective study is to evaluate the influence of this algorithm on coagulation, use of blood products, coagulation factors and ROTEM evolution.

detailed_description.textblock:
In 2008 at the USZ a massive transfusion protocol was introduced. Based on laboratory diagnostics and POC (point of care) devices including ROTEM.
Goal of this retrospective study is to evaluate the influence of this algorithm on coagulation, use of blood products, coagulation factors and ROTEM evolution over three years (2008-2010)

primary_outcome.description: Point of care devices are used in bleeding patients. In the university hospital of Zurich an algorithm in the case of massive bleeding was introduced in 2008. The primary outcome measure is to investigate the changes of ROTEM parameters in the sense of amelioration reflected by better coagulation by using goal directed transfusions.

secondary_outcome.description: To evaluate the blood products and coagulation factors needed and to evaluate if there is a reduction between the time before the introduction of the algorithm compared to afterwards.

intervention.description: In bleeding patients point of care measurements are performed, in this case Rotational Thromboelastometry (ROTEM) to guide the use of blood products and coagulation factors.

study_pop.textblock: All patients needing massive transfusion (more than 10 RBCs)
